In addition to above, we should only require the new property if relative paths exist and check the existence of all files before renaming relative paths.  We need to make sure the value in the new property is absolutely correct before renaming metadata paths.

Also need to check delete markers for relative paths.

We could not add the new property and only add the rate limiter with a hard coded rate.  This bad server handling has a count that is not currently configurable.  So adding the rate limiter w/o a configuration option would just add one more constants to the bad server handling code.  The reason I am thinking this is that I am trying to determine what positive value the bad server handling code has, it may be that if we can not determine what the benefit is that we should remove the code.  If we add a configuration knob know, it would make that decision more complex.  I am not sure this course of action should be taken, just something I was thinking about and wanted to post if for discussion.

Yeah, I considered that initially but It was decided to have a solution that could update last location periodically so even tables that have been stagnant for a while would have their most up to date location. I will look into it more.

I think that makes sense.

I agree with @keith-turner. I'm not sure this code shouldn't be removed. I removed the property in the latest commit. Personally, I think this should be a situation where we log and take no action. I could be convinced otherwise but at this time I can't come up with a reason that we should keep it.

@alerman, what do you think about making the changes only for the next version of Accumulo (2.1, which is under development)? I see your pull request is against the 1.9 branch. Adding new features or behavior changes to an older stable release is something that makes me a bit nervous and I feel reluctant to encourage or support, unless there's a strong argument for it. I'd feel more comfortable restricting changes to bug fixes only... and not behavior changes or feature adds, even if they are internal and not user facing... unless there's a very good argument. What do you think?

@ctubbsii I agree that new features shouldn't necessarily end up in 1.9, but in this case, I believe this change in behavior is required. In the event that the master has an intermittent network issue (something we have seen on other nodes often) the entire cluster could be taken out. That seems like a behavior that we can't allow to remain as-is. Especially considering that this branch may be the basis for the first LTS release (if that is still planned).

I am perfectly fine with taking the discussion of whether to remove this behavior entirely to 2.x, but as it stands I believe this is a necessary safeguard to currently deployed 1.9 releases.

I think the behavior @alerman saw was undesirable and I would call it buggy.  I think this change w/o the property may improve the situation and qualify as a bug fix.  I do share the concern about this change causing new bugs, but that can be mitigated with targeted testing of the change and code review.

>  I could be convinced otherwise but at this time I can't come up with a reason that we should keep it.

I think there were legitimate use cases that this code was addressing.  Need to try to enumerate those if possible.  I opened #1460

I think we should stop the halt of tservers for 1.9 and just spam the log that the tserver is not responding.  The change in behavior would be stopping a dangerous behavior.  Similar to the check we recently added to prevent dangerous behavior of cloning of the metadata table.   We should only change a few lines of code for 1.9 and then refactor in 2.1.

@ctubbsii After fixing the first error in VolumeChooserIT (which was that ClientContext was always reading the instance ID from ZooKeeper), we saw another error from PerTableVolumeChooser that was due to no volume chooser being configured for the init or default scope. Previously, the user could just configure a volume chooser for the logger scope, since that was the only scope where we were constructing a volume chooser. Since introducing volume choosers for the init scope would require the user to change their config, Karthick's latest patch falls back to a random chooser when the neither the desired nor the default scope are specified. This preserves the old behavior for the init scope, but changes the behavior for the logger scope (which previously threw an error instead of falling back to random).

> Karthick's latest patch falls back to a random chooser when the neither the desired nor the default scope are specified.

@billierinaldi the comments on #253 discuss reasons for avoiding falling back to the random chooser.  I am not sure if those reasons apply to these changes though, just wanted to make you aware of those.

Thanks, @keith-turner. I did see that issue, which was why I wanted to explicitly discuss the desired behavior. My impression from reading over the comments was that it was decided that misconfiguration should definitely throw an error, but I was less clear on whether it is important that absent configuration should throw an error. I suppose there are three possibilities:

1. require a new configuration property when using the preferred and per table volume choosers (general.custom.volume.preferred.default or general.custom.volume.preferred.init must be specified)
2. fall back to the random chooser instead of throwing an exception when scope-specific and default properties are not specified (absent configuration no longer throws an error for the logger scope, implemented in the current patch)
3. handle absent configuration differently for the logger and init scopes, so that init falls back to random while logger throws an exception (preserving existing behavior for both scopes, while allowing new configurability for the init scope).

My order of preference is 2, 3, 1, but I am open to any of these and to other suggestions.

Based on the intent of the previous issue, only option 1 seems acceptable to me, as it is the only one that properly protects against partial / improper configuration. Any fall-back to a random chooser can place data improperly on a system, that is very expensive to correct later. In general, I think it's a good idea to require explicit configuration from a user, rather than the system to try to infer user's intentions from incomplete or incorrect configuration.

The behavior I strongly prefer: the default config should work out of the box, without any special configuration (it does, as the default is the `RandomVolumeChooser`), but if the other choosers are used, they *must* be fully configured, with explicit configuration for any relevant scope they will be executed for. Here, I think this means that during system initialization, the corresponding init scope configuration property, or the default scope property, must be set.

> @ctubbsii Are there semver implications to changing how the PerTableVolumeChooser and PreferredVolumeChooser need to be configured?

I don't think we consider our configuration to be "public API" in the same way that our Java API is "public API" for the purposes of semver. The "custom" props that we support for various implementation-specific classes of server-side plugin mechanisms even less so (they are more like API for that specific plugin, rather than "Accumulo" API), but it's all still user-facing, so we should be careful. I ran some performance test using the commands below.  These were run on single VM with 16GB of ram and 10 tservers ( I need to run them again w/ more resources, I think the box was stressed).

```bash
# create 100K random 8 char split points
$ cat /dev/urandom | base32 -w 8 | head -100000 | sort -u > splits.txt

# create a table and split it
$ accumulo shell -u root -p secret
root@uno> createtable foo
root@uno foo> addsplits -t foo -sf splits.txt
root@uno> quit

# after tablets balance, kill all tservers
$ pkill -f tserver

# after waiting a bit, restart tservers
$ tup.sh

# I periodically ran the following command to see how many tablets were assigned but not loaded
$ accumulo shell -u root -p secret -e 'scan -t accumulo.metadata -c future -np' | grep future | wc

# I periodically ran the following command to see what the user tablet assignment thread is up to
$ jstack <master pid> | grep -A 30 'Watching Normal'
```

For testing, it would be nice to be able to make a tserver not halt when it looses its lock in ZK.  The master would thinks its dead, but it would keep running.  I can think of three ways to accomplish this.  

First, we could just make it configurable but this feels wrong.  

Second we could write some code in accumulo-testing that uses byte buddy to create a java agent which mutates the behavior of the tablet server code.  I did something like this for [nanoop](https://github.com/keith-turner/nanoop).  Maybe there is an easier way to mutate the behavior of compiled java code.
